results.title: Costa Rica
results.creator_credit: Rolando Quiros, Horst Cerns, UNICEF and Japanese TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Families of the world”.
Captures the flavour of life on a Costa Rican coffee plantation during harvest time when the whole family helps. At harvest’s end the family joins the village fiesta, parading by day and revelling by night.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rolando Quiros, Horst Cerns, UNICEF and Japanese TV

results.title: Families of the world
results.brief_description: This series of 6 videos enables children to compare and contrast their lives with those of children from other nations. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Family house
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An artistic treatment of what constitutes a change in the philosophy of family housing. Made from still photographs and nostalgic Victorian paintings, and based on an essay by the distinguished Canadian architect Humphrey Carver, the film contrasts the traditional romantic image of the home as domicile from cradle to grave with the needs of today’s more transient urban population. The film is designed to stimulate thought and discussion about housing and town planning.

results.title: Australia
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Stewart MacLennan and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Families of the world”.
Join 11 year-old Catherine Inall and learn about her life in Sydney and her Christmas summer vacation on a sheep farm in remote northern New South Wales. Catherine participates in a way of life that is both new to her and unique to Australia. Designed for students from the Northern hemisphere, it is interesting to look at Australian life from a foreigner’s perspective. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Family down the Fraser
results.creator_credit: Tony Westman, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Richard and Rochelle Wright and their two sons travelled the Fraser River from Cache Tete Jaune to the Pacific coast in a rubber raft. In addition to being a great adventure, the trip brought them into contact with people who told them some of the history of the river, and acquainted them with lifestyles vastly different from their own citified ways.

results.title: Family day care [Greek version]
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Designed to describe all aspects of the family Day Care Scheme, financed by the Department of Social Security, the film follows a co-ordinator of a scheme in the inner Sydney suburb Marackville. Through her day-to-day experiences we see different kinds of care being given to children’s differing needs and we see colourful experiences designed for the children by highly skilled care-givers. Cinematography by John Hosking. In Greek and English.

results.title: Family day care
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Additional credits are: script- Karl McPhee; photographer- John Hosking; editor- Karl Sodersten; sound- Max Hensser, Julian Ellingworth. Pam Goodwin is one of the co-ordinators of a Family Day Care Program. Her job entails interviewing parents and helping them find the kind of care that they want for their children, and interviewing the women who want to mind children and helping them in this role.

results.title: Faites Sauter la Banque = Rob the Bank
results.brief_description:
Garnier, a shopkeeper, gets taken advantage of by a local banker, Durand-Mareuil. Having lost everything on the stock exchange, he decides to get his money back by digging a tunnel under the bank all the way to the safes.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Jean Girault ; writers, Jacques Girault, Jacques Vilfrid, Louis Sapin ; photography, Andre Germain ; music, Paul Mauriat.
Cast: Louis de Funes, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Anne Doat, Yvonne Clech, Claude Pieplu, Catherine Demongeot, Georges Wilson.

results.title: Fairytales and Fantasy Workshops: Carlton North Primary 18 July 2005: Groups A and B
results.brief_description:
Fairy Tales and Fantasy is an ACMI screen education program designed to encourage students to begin to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms, by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. Fairy Tales and Fantasy aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts. Students in Years 1-2 learn about:
- three key stages of plot development
- main elements of the fairy tale genre
- simple concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, angles
- the magic of blue-screen technology
- become actors in a short film during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a magical, fairy tale setting
- engage with a film program featuring traditional and non-traditional fairy tales, and participate in a related discussion
- learn some simple editing skills while they create a fairy tale story
- view their ACMI creations.
Fairy Tales and Fantasy and activities provided in the accompanying Teacher Kit are designed to assist students to develop a range of Screen Literacy outcomes. The program is also designed to assist students to develop understandings about the ways in which stories help us to make sense of the world and our place in that world. People all over the world tell stories in many different ways using oral, written and visual texts. This program and related activities enables students to share their experiences of story and to extend and refine their understandings by comparing a range of fairy tale and fantasy texts, analysing narrative structure and exploring animation and film adaptations of fairy tales.
